text:
Izuku didn’t even find out from Katsuki himself.
 
It’s one of those things you catch out of the corner of your eye. Izuku does a double, a triple take; he jumps right into his social media, going through the five stages of grief, and he might’ve invented a sixth along the way.
It’s plastered all over the news, and Katsuki comes strolling into Izuku’s apartment like nothing is wrong (because he stole the spare key two years ago and refuses to give it back).
The door is kicked open, and it hits the foam pad Izuku glued there specifically for that reason.
“I brought soba for your smallass, ‘cause I know you skipped dinner at the firm,” Katsuki says, arms full and his face still faintly smudged black from the mask.
Izuku rolls his eyes at the term small. Despite their height difference, they’re actually pretty close in weight.
“Oh no no no,” Izuku sings. “Don’t think you’re going to win my favor with food, Kacchan.”
Katsuki pauses in the kitchen. He gives the most scorching, evil glare, and he tips his head like a dog in question.
“Hah?”
Izuku points to the television, where it says TMZ NEWS: Hero Ground Zero Caught Smooching Blue Bombshell! 
“Two months?” Izuku waves at the scrolling text. “You’ve been dating a girl for two months?” 
Katsuki’s face falls back to his bored, neutral state, and he turns to unload the food on the counter.
“And? Whata’bout it? A guy can’t get laid around here?”
Izuku stands off the couch, kidding but kind of appalled. “You didn’t tell me! ME! I’ve known you since diapers and I’m offended. Best friend card is officially redacted.”
“Stay pressed,” Katsuki snorts. “I don’t have to tell you shit about my life.”
And while Izuku had been kind-of joking, that hits him real bad. It’s that kind of heavy — get the wind knocked out of you — feeling. Izuku sits back down on the couch and flips the channel.
“Right.”
“And I’m keeping the best friend card – scoot your ass, fucker,” Katsuki grunts, and climbs over the back of the couch. Izuku already has his hand ready to receive the takeout, and he catches it without looking. “You better eat all that, or you owe me my money back.”
Izuku sticks out his tongue and snatches the chopsticks out of Katsuki’s hand before he can stab him with them.
“Why don’t you go run off with your shiny new girlfriend?” 
Katsuki rolls his eyes dramatically, and gives a look that would kill a lesser man.
“Do not start with that. Give me the damn remote.”
 
Izuku eats quietly to keep the peace, and ignores the overwhelming feeling like his entire world is falling apart.
 
 
 
Because here’s the thing.
 
 
 
Izuku doesn’t actually know how many people Katsuki has dated. To his own knowledge, Katsuki has been a hit it and quit it kind of guy – and Izuku was comfortable with that. Katsuki would tell him details if a pickup was particularly bad (or funny), but it helped Izuku’s peace of mind. Katsuki is emotionally unavailable. Katsuki doesn’t date.
 
Right?
 
Apparently, it’s none of his business.
 

But why now? 


 

It’s not like Katsuki is unattractive. It’s actually the opposite. Kaachan was at the tattoo parlor the very day he turned eighteen, and he caught a good whooping from his mom for coming home with half a sleeve.
He cuts his hair shorter, now. And he’s built and tall, god – it’s really unfair, Izuku still gets pissed about that growth spurt. But really, they’re the top two heroes in Japan; an ongoing score that changes by the day. If you ignore some personality flaws, Katsuki really is a catch.
Maybe it’s their age. They turn twenty-five this year; but it’s not like Izuku has love knocking down his door. Uh, for a few reasons, actually.
Love. The word makes him a bit sick.
 
Izuku looks over, and Katsuki is sitting with a leg up on the couch, elbow braced on his knee as he scowls at the TV. Izuku’s heart churns and squeezes like it always does. That’s okay. Izuku is well seasoned at playing along by now.
 
“Scho,” Izuku chews. “If you’re not going to tell me about your new partner, I guess I’ll just have to deduct it myself. Blue hair, black clothes – did you guys meet at a bar? Oh, maybe she’s in a band. Did you finally get the goth girlfriend of your dreams? Hmm, or maybe she has a water quirk –”
“I am going to chuck my hearing aids across the room if you do not fucking shut up,” Katsuki barks like a dog, and the familiarity makes Izuku smile.
“Your eye twitched. It was a band. What’s she play, drums? Guitar? Bass?” Twitch. “Ah, it was bass.”
Kaachan’s hearing aids hit the wall with a very loud clatter.
 
You’re paying for those, Izuku signs. Katsuki flips him off – and that, Izuku can read.
 
 
 
 
They call her Katsuki’s girl. 
 
Izuku has only met her twice in a month and a half. Katsuki seems determined to keep them as far away from each other as possible, and Izuku hasn’t figured out why.
 
Kacchan doesn’t really get embarrassed, but he can be kind of private about his personal life. Izuku had hoped maybe they were past that, given how deeply both their personal and work lives intertwine – but apparently not.
 
Katsuki’s girl. She has a normal name – Chiyou, he thinks. Izuku can’t be jealous of something he will never have, but it’s a timeless pain that feels brand new. It’s as if he’s thirteen again, writing a name in the margin of his notes, over and over like if he repeats it enough, then maybe he can have the impossible.
To say Izuku grew out of his feelings – that would be a lie. It’s more like… reluctant acceptance. Like the scars down his arms.
 
Everything is normal at work. They’ve owned the joint firm for running on what, five years now? Heroes come and go, but their old 1A classmates seem to stay. Izuku tells himself it’s a good thing, because it is.  
“Where’s Ochaco?” Izuku asks, spinning his desk chair.
“Called out,” Denki snaps his gum. “To replace our lovely Kacchan.” 
“He’d kill you if he heard you say that,” Eijirou laughs.
“It’s not fair,” Denki sighs. “Only Izuku is allowed to call him cute pet names.”
“A terrible privilege,” Izuku jokes. He then blinks, “Wait, where is Kacchan? He’d rather be skinned alive than miss work.”
“The lady demanded a sacrifice,” Eijirou says in a medieval voice. “Leave thy work and pay for mine dinner, or suffer hence balls blue.”
Denki takes a moment to process that, but he then slaps the table and cackles, “She cut him off! That is fucking hilarious!” 
“I know! Apparently, Baku-bro does have a weakness.”
Izuku flips his pen around in his fingers, and frowns. The reports stare back at him.
“Does…Kacchan bring Chiyou-san around you guys?”
Eijirou pauses, mid tying up his hair. It’s gotten long, so long that it can hardly stay in a single rubber band. Katsuki’s friends can be kind of dense, but they’re hard workers and great heroes, and Izuku can now call them his own friends, too.
“Huh? You mean his girl? Nah.”
“He’s embarrassed ‘cause he gets all romantic,” Denki makes a kissy face, and Eijirou slaps his face away lightly.
“Gross! Dude, he’s probably just playing it safe so you don’t run her off with your dank BO.”
“I don’t s— wait.” Denki sniffs under his arm, and Izuku smiles.
“You do, sorry man.”
Sero appears over the divider, “Naughty naughty. Dirty boys are sentenced to the piss chamber.”
Izuku rolls his eyes, “The communal showers are not that bad.”
“They smell real musky, dude,” Eijirou admits.
Izuku drowns out of the conversation when he gets a backup alert from Ochaco. He’s gone in a quick costume change, and he’s glad to have something else to think about.
 
 
He sees her in tabloids, sometimes. Katsuki’s girl.
She’s cute. A baby blue bob, tan skin, freckles with a dark, fashionable clothing style. Maybe Izuku is just petty – but it’s hard to imagine Katsuki getting along with anyone, let alone…what? Dating? As much as Izuku tries not to think about it, Katsuki is always haunting the back of his mind.
 

Does he hold her hand? Does he buy her nice things? Does he kiss her goodnight? 


 


Does he love her? 


 


 

The thought makes Izuku’s stomach cramp so hard, he becomes nauseous.
 
As impossible as it is, Izuku can’t help but wonder what it would be like to be called Katsuki’s girl. 
 
 
 

 

Katsuki doesn’t give up their hangout nights. How he manages to balance it all, Izuku does not know.
 
“I’m surprised you showed up,” Izuku says, grabbing drinks and mixers out of the fridge.
Katsuki narrows his eyes in suspicion, and hunts through Izuku’s cabinets for glasses.
“Why?”
Izuku whistles, “You tore me a new one today. I haven’t seen you that mad since, shit. UA?”
Katsuki grinds his teeth and snatches the rum out of Izuku’s hand.
“Do not remind me. I swear to Christ if you go all self-sacrificing martyr on me one more goddamn time, I’m going to shove my foot so far up your ass you’re gonna’ taste my boot.”
“Kinky,” Izuku says. Katsuki tries to catch him in a headlock, and Izuku dips under his arm.
It’s an age-old battle; one gets hurt, the other gets pissed. Round and round in circles – at this point its tradition more than a real fight.
“I’ve got the reports for that hybrid gang,” Izuku says.
Katsuki pauses mid pour, and raises an eyebrow.
“You wanna’ do work while you’re blasted?”
“It wouldn’t be the first time, right?”
Katsuki actually snorts, and uses a spare chopstick to mix the drink.
“Hey Kacchan, let’s start our own firm, Kacchan, it’ll be a great idea, Kacchan –”
“Oh shoot,” Izuku rubs his forehead. “I forgot about our taxes.”
“I dropped them off because I know you’re a moron,” Katsuki says, and pushes a drink to Izuku’s chest. “Where’s the stupid reports?”
“Desk.”
Katsuki slides across his kitchen island instead of walking around it like a normal human being, and Izuku laughs, because he knows if he tried that at Katsuki’s apartment, he’d get torn a new asshole.
He watches Katsuki rummage through his desk like he knows where everything is (because he does), and even the distraction of liquor doesn’t help the burn in his stomach.
Izuku leans up against the counter, and rests his cup at his bottom lip. Katsuki is broad, with a slim waist and firm, inked up arms. The tattoos don’t mean anything, and Katsuki gets pissed when he’s constantly asked about it. He doesn’t skip leg day, but you’d never know from all the baggy pants he wears.
“Hey Kacchan,” Izuku calls.
“Hm.”
“Real talk, for a second?”
Katsuki gives him a sideways look. They have their ups and downs, but they’ve slowly built a relationship out of respect, and they know when the other is being serious.
“What’s up?”
“Is this really okay?” Izuku asks. Katsuki hates unclear questions, and his eye twitches in forced patience, so Izuku quickly continues, “I mean – I don’t want Chiyou-san to feel abandoned just because we have a tradition. I really don’t mind if you want to spend more time with her.”
Katsuki’s lid pops, for a second.
“Eh? You sayin’ I’m a crap boyfriend? You don’t think I know how to balance my shit like a fucking adult? You want me gone, is that it?”
Izuku frowns.
“Kacchan.”
Izuku watches him regain composure. Katsuki seethes angrily, and runs through his age old anger management of breathing in, counting to five, and rewording his question.
“Why do you say that?”
Izuku shrugs a shoulder, and picks at the old half-peeled barcode sticker at the bottom of his cup.
“I don’t want you to force yourself.”
“I never do shit I don’t wanna’ do,” Katsuki scowls, crossing his arms. “Is that all? Does that help your soft little feelings?”  
Izuku rolls his eyes, but laughs, “You are such an asshole.”
“Surprise, surprise. I found your shit, by the way. If you don’t organize this fucking cabinet I’m going to come in and do it for you.”
“Nooo,” Izuku whines, “I have everything where I want it!”
“This,” Katsuki lifts up a manila folder stuffed with papers, “Is not organized. This is how you lost our taxes last year.”
“I already told you I was sorry about that. At least I didn’t blow up the evidence for the Muna case.”
“That was not my fault and you know it.”
 
 
Izuku hates tabloids. They always find his bad angles and size them up approximately three-hundred times too big. You learn to ignore the gossip in this line of work, but it’s still difficult to turn a blind eye to the electric billboards and the countless magazine stands.
“Jeez,” Izuku grits, and tucks his hands in his kangaroo pocket. “I just wanted some fried rice. Is that too much to ask for?”
“Apparently,” Shouto says, and he looks silly in his round sunglasses and his hoodie string pulled tight around his face. Unfortunately, his hair is way too recognizable to be walking into a street bodega at night, so.
Shouto is also a jerk because he took a hit off the same growth spurt Katsuki had. He’s transitioned from pretty-boy to a pretty-man, and he’s a hot commodity for the commercial world, but it sucks for them because Shouto couldn’t give less of a damn about anything other than hero work.
Shouto grabs one of the magazines for a closer look. Half of the spread is a photoshoot of Momo, and the other half is collaged paparazzi photos of Katsuki and Chiyou exiting a movie theater. Katsuki’s arm is loose around her waist, and suddenly Izuku isn’t hungry anymore. Jeez, Izuku is such an asshole, but it’s not like he can lie to himself.
“This is just weird,” Shouto mumbles. “Almost…wrong. Like watching someone bite the top off a kit-kat bar.”
“That was a dig,” Izuku points.
“You’re a heathen,” Shouto replies. He sets down the mag, and looks back to Izuku. His eyes are hidden, but Izuku can see a red eyebrow rise above his lenses. “Are you really okay with all this?”
Shouto is the only one who knows about Izuku’s feelings, but that’s because Shouto found him sobbing hysterically in a bathroom on prom night, and he sat on his legs and twisted his arm until Izuku told him the truth.
“It’s fine,” Izuku shrugs. “I mean, no. But it’s fine.”
Shouto stops walking, and Izuku internally groans, because he knows Shouto is about to press him.
“No?”
“It’s – I’m happy for him, really. But, he doesn’t talk about her. Doesn’t want us to meet. Doesn’t want me involved at all.”
“That’s a good thing, isn’t it…?”
Izuku steps up on the curb, so that they’re no longer standing in a vacant parking spot.
“No. Well…you could look at it that way. But it hurts more knowing he doesn’t want me involved in that part of his life at all.” Izuku rubs his eyes on his forearm, “Like, shit. I don’t know what’s better. Maybe a meteor will take me off the planet and solve all my problems.”
“I wouldn’t count on it,” Shouto says, and begins walking again. “But something smells wrong here.”
Izuku eyes him.
“What do you mean?”
Shouto shrugs, and holds open the shop door.
“Bakugou Katsuki, your beloved Kacchan and personal shadow, doesn’t want you to get along with his romantic interest? It sounds suspicious. Maybe he’s afraid you won’t approve.” Izuku gives him a very skeptical look, and Shouto rolls his eyes. “Alright, have at me.”
Izuku lists off his fingers.
“A, he is not my shadow, I’m actually certain it’s the other way around and B, Kacchan? Afraid?? Of my opinion? Did you even process those words before you said them?”
“A, it goes both ways and B yes I did.”
“You are high,” Izuku says. He sucks air through his lips and motions by his lips, “Absolutely off your rocker.”
“Not since yesterday.” Shouto nods towards the menu. “What do you want?”
“Some fried rice please.”
Shouto pays for their food and they walk back towards the Todoroki hero firm, knowing they can sneak in the back without getting spotted by the night shift.
Izuku was happy that Shouto decided to take over Endeavor’s firm when presented with the opportunity. It’s a much larger scale than what Katsuki and Izuku run back in the Shibuya district, but they work closely together for intel and resources, and Japan has taken to calling them The Big Three. 
“I could pull some strings,” Shouto suggests, sitting up on his desk as he eats. “You know, a little,” he makes a clicking sound and a whistle, and jabs over his shoulder. Izuku lifts his eyebrows, and Shouto explains, “Just a couple calls. Make sure Bakugou doesn’t date in this city ever again.”
“I am appalled and disgusted that you would suggest that,” Izuku scoffs. He then jokingly winks, and Shouto cackles in the ugly way that only a few get to hear.
“Just saying.”
“I wish I could’ve fallen in love with you,” Izuku sighs, cracking his chopsticks. “My life would be easier.”
“I’m too emotionally and physically unavailable,” Shouto says, tipping his head back to try and pool a very long noodle in his mouth, all manners gone this late at night. “I’d drive you crazy. But I’m still here whenever you decide to get platonically married.”
“I’ll keep that in mind.”
 
 
Izuku comes home to find all his lights on.
 
His defenses are raised, but they fall as soon as he sees Katsuki supine on his couch.
“Honey I’m home,” Izuku jokes.
“Where the fuck have you been?” Katsuki glares ferociously, shoving in his hearing aids. “Your phone better be at the bottom of the ocean.”
“Uh, shoot,” Izuku pats his back pockets. “Sorry, I was – wait. Why are you in my apartment?”
“I got stat leaks for the new UA interns,” Katsuki waves a packet around. “We have until tomorrow to make our picks before all the good ones are snatched up.”
The nasty look Katsuki is throwing him makes Izuku feel more like he’s the one dating Katsuki, and that train of thought is too painful to follow, so Izuku dumps his wallet and keys on the counter and makes his way across the living room.
“Don’t talk about children that way, they’re all talented and we will be lucky to have any of them.”
“This dude has a skunk quirk.”
“…Okay, maybe not that one.”
 
Katsuki spreads out photocards and stat papers, and Izuku can smell his aftershave from sitting this close on the couch – but all Izuku can think about is Katsuki’s arm wrapped around his girlfriend’s petite little waist.
Katsuki has a nice profile. He’s saying stuff Izuku should be paying attention to, but it’s nearly one in the morning, and Izuku feels himself not-quite on planet earth.
 Someone else gets to kiss him. Someone else gets to sneak pictures of Katsuki sleeping while petting through short spikey hair. The more he thinks about it, the more Izuku’s heart feels like it’s being strangled to death, and he doesn’t realize he’s breathing heavy until Katsuki is up in his face.
“Hey, Deku! Are you even listening to me you fucking – woah, hey.” Katsuki’s tone drops, and it’s like all the jagged edges buff out into smooth, calm sandstone, and Izuku feels like he could just wash away into dust. He’s brought back by a hand squeezing tight into his knee. “Deku. Are you with me?”
“Yeah, I’m – yeah.” Izuku scrubs at his eyes. “Sorry, kinda’ tired. I’m impressed you’re up this late.”
“Slept in for an afternoon shift,” Katsuki explains offhandedly. He frowns, and his eyebrows are always pushed together so tightly, Izuku yearns to smooth over them with his fingers. “Hey, where the fuck did you go tonight? You don’t look right.”
“That’s not very nice, Kacchan,” Izuku teases lightly, but the look Katsuki gives him says that won’t fly, and Izuku knows it. “I was with Shouto. It’s really nothing.”
Katsuki’s eyes shine pink sometimes, when the light hits them right. He looks into Izuku, through him, like he’s x-raying to check all his bones. Izuku used to think it was pure malice, but he now knows there’s concern etched in there. That’s almost worse.
“Fine. We’ll make our picks and I’ll get out of your stupid hair.”
Izuku hums sleepily and folds his head in his hand. “You can stay the night.”
Katsuki lifts an eyebrow, and Izuku tries to figure out what he said wrong, until he stutters.
“Oh! G-girlfriend! Right, my bad.” Izuku laughs a little to play it off. “I forget you’re not single like the rest of us losers.”
“That has nothing to do with it,” Katsuki grunts, but leans over his knees to start shuffling papers around again. “Just switch into nerd mode, dumbass.”
Izuku takes one last glance at the fuzzy, warm nape of Katsuki’s neck, before he leans over and starts to analyze the statistics.
 
 
Katsuki leaves within the hour. Izuku has never thought to ask for the spare key back, but…maybe he should.
 
 
 
 
His life is a lot of work and no play, but that’s okay when you like what you do. Izuku is good at search and rescue, and Katsuki excels at villain takedown, but that doesn’t mean they can’t switch.
 
Izuku likes to push his body as far as it can go. The world moves in slow motion as he kicks between buildings, jumping into the air and tackling a villain to the ground. Katsuki is always right where he needs him to be, grabbing up lost civilians and shouting (impatient) commands to clear the area.
When electricity cuts through the alley, Izuku knows he doesn’t have to worry about the few that got away.
“You stole my fuckin’ move,” Katsuki snaps, a teenage boy slung over his shoulder. He’s long abandoned the grenade gauntlets for smaller, more functional gloves, and only the tops of his tattoos are visible around his bicep.
“Sorry,” Izuku laughs. “It’s the most efficient way to cut through buildings without breaking windows.”
“Well shit, it’s not like our insurance can take another hit.”
“Can you put me down already!?!” The kid wails, slapping Katsuki’s back.
“No. You still need to be checked out by an EMT, so shut your hole.”   
The villain gurgles under Izuku’s grip, and Izuku slides off to cuff him, rolling the man to his side.
“I’m all good here if you want to go check on 7th street,” Izuku offers.
“Don’t tell me what to do. Also are you still down for dinner, or what?”
 
It’s a Friday night, Izuku thinks. What about your girlfriend? 

 

“So long as it’s okay with Chiyou-san,” Izuku says. Katsuki rolls his eyes.
“Like I give a fuck what she thinks. Just meet us at the bar, Shitty-hair is coming too.”
Izuku almost feels bad for her, but he doesn’t have the time to think too much on it. The road smells like burnt asphalt and sirens are buzzing two streets down.
“Sounds good. I’ll check and see who’s off schedule.”
“Can we wrap this up already?” The kid huffs. The villain snorts into the concrete.
“Yeah, yer tyin’ the cuffs a lil’ too tight, sweetcheeks.”
“Shut up,” Izuku and Katsuki say. And then an additional please from Izuku.
 
 
The owner of the bar knows them by now, so it’s not worth hiding their identities.
“The half-safest bar in the east!” The owner claims, because a room full of heroes can go two different ways.
Sero and Mina are off chatting up waitresses, so they’re automatically counted out of the next round of darts. Katsuki throws one-twenty during his round, and Izuku shakes his head as he pulls the darts out of the board.
“You’re putting me in a real hard spot, Kacchan.”
“Fuck off, dipshit over here pushed my arm.”
Eijirou laughs, “It worked, didn’t it?”
“Hell yeah, teamwork!” Denki high-fives him.
“Don’t fuck up,” Katsuki calls.  
Izuku throws a fifty, and then a nineteen.
“Fuck!” Katsuki curses, and slams back his drink. “You two are on my shit list, fuckin’ cheaters, I hope you die tonight.”
“Awww, that’s so sweet.”
The bar is busy and loud, and their laughter drowns in with the noise. Izuku doesn’t mind social gatherings, if it’s somewhere he’s familiar with. Anxiety always buzzes at the back of his mind these days, but less so with his friends.
Eijirou and Denki are fresh out of costume in sweats and t-shirts, but Katsuki always looks fashionable, even when he’s not trying to be. Baggy-jeans, soft hoodie and a baseball cap backwards on his head; he doesn’t look approachable by any means, but Izuku likes that about him.
Izuku throws his last dart and laughs, “One-nineteen. So damn close.”
“Drink up,” Eijirou offers a shot and grins, and Izuku cringes as he knocks it back.
“Lord, that’s so bad.”
“We’ve done six!” Denki fights, leaning up against the bar table. “You guys can spare to lose once.”
“Sure, but you’re taking the interns on Monday,” Bakugou says, and Izuku starts to laugh.
“No! No way! That’s so not fair.”
Eijirou elbows Denki, “That’s what we get for drinkin’ with our bosses.”
Izuku pretends to gag at the word boss, and Katsuki digs his knuckles into the top of Eijirou’s head.
“Watch your goddamn mouth, or you’re on kid duty all week.”
Eijirou giggles because he knows it’s an empty threat.
“So mean! Shouldn’t you go home to your girl already?”
“Shut up, don’t act like you know shit.”
Izuku tries to fall out of the conversation, but Denki is quick to wrap an arm around his shoulders.
“What about you, huh? Still going on blind dates?”
Katsuki pauses, mid-dig into Eijirou’s skull.
“Blind what?”
Izuku ignores him; “Not anymore. I told Ochaco I was done after the uh…the last one.”
“Ah, right.”
Katsuki gets puffy and agitated, “Hey, you didn’t say shit about no date.”
Like he has any room to talk, but Izuku is too tired to fight him on it.
Izuku rubs the back of his head, “Well, that’s ‘cause um…it didn’t end very well. I kind of uh…spilled wine down his pants and accidentally flipped the table over when I stood up to help him.”
“Poor guy ran off?” Eijirou asks.
“Yeah.”
Katsuki squints at him, but then rests back against the stair railing.
“Hmph, coward. Anyone should know you come with a warning label.”
Izuku can’t figure out if that was a compliment or not, but Denki jostles him and pokes his nose.
“You just need to get back out there! Shit dude, you’re the Number One hero, you’ve got fanclubs out there just itchin’ to get in your pants. You’re built like a brick house and your ass is fuckin’ bomb, any guy would be lucky to slap that– no homo.”
Eijirou lifts his cup, “Amen!”
Izuku isn’t sober enough to handle this. He feels his face getting hotter, and the mixture of alcohol and embarrassment makes his age-old stutter come back like he’s fifteen again.
“W-well I… it’s not like – I mean –”
“Eff off,” Katsuki grunts, kicking his foot into the back of Denki’s heel. “Quit actin’ like a stud, you fuckin’ virgin.”
“Ow! Ex-cuuuse you, I’m saving myself for marriage.”  
“Right. And Marriage is six-feet tall with purple hair –”

“SHUT UP SHUT UP SHUT UP!” 

 
 
Eijirou doesn’t mind kid duty all that much. You know, teaching the next gen and all that jazz – it’s cool, it’s cool. Eijirou got to pick his own shadows this year, so he’s got two baby UA first years that are so cute he could just eat them.
Eijirou likes picking kids that could use the confidence boost, anyways. 
“Just like that!” Eijirou claps, as miss self-named Arachnida sets down a boulder with all six arms. “Great job! Looks like we’re clear of civilians here.”
“Thank you-che,” Arachnida bows.
The other intern, a green kid named Kale, bounces on his feet.
“What now?”
“Well, next we have to –”
He stops when he hears Katsuki yelling. He and Izuku are speaking with the chief of police, and their conversation is loud enough to carry across the cracked road. The two of them hold a strong presence when they’re on scene; a no-nonsense tone that makes all the other heroes want to work their hardest.
